Several additional engagements
have been scheduled by the'Musical
Club for the current season, according to an announcement by
Norman S. Heaney, president of
the organization.
A full concert will be given at the
Y. M. H. A. on Sunday, April 15,
at 8:00 p. in. The Blue Jay orchestra will play at the dance to follow
the concert.

manager of athletics.

long and tireing- discussion, which
has' always terminated in no action,
because of lack of necessary funds."

were over a hundred thousand dollars and included the construction
of side rooms, locker and shower
rooms.

HOME WOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 6, 1934

ltemsen Club
Elects Officers
Sachs Heads Chemistry Association Sponsored By
Dr. Neil E. Gordon
At the organization meeting of
he newly founded Remsen Chemistry Club, Robert G. Sachs was
named president of the organization.
The other officers elected were
vice-president, Ned Railing, secretary, Laurence Weiss; treasurer,
Richard Schlotterback ;• and sergeant-at-arms, Floyd Katske.
FOUNDED BY DR. GORDON

The club, started by Dr. Neil E.
Gordon, is an honorary association
the purpose of which is to further
interest in chemistry and to bring
the members into closer contact
with the subject. Although it is a
freshman undertaking, members of
other classes are eligible for membership.
No constitution has as yet been
adopted, but one is being formulated and will be voted upon at the
regular meeting, Thursday. Tentative membership and program committees have been appointed.
The lattter group has announced
that arrangements are being made
to secure prominent speakers.

Dr. Jack Sparer, who was_a high

hostilities and organized 18 New

Evers On The Hitler
Regime Today At 1 P. M.
The Rev. Fritz 0. Evers, Zion
Church, Baltimore, will discuss
"The Reactions of the German
People to the Hitler Regime" before the Liberal Club in Room B,
Levering Hall, today at 1 p. in.
Dr. Evers has recently returned
from a several weeks stay in Germany, where as a former German
citizen he had ample opportunity to
observe the feelings of the people
toward their new government.
IS PROMINENT PREACHER.
As a young man, Dr. Evers came
to this country at the beginning of
the century. He preached in Englewood, New Jersey, for a number of
years and then went to Zion Church
Philadelphia. About five years ago
he came to Baltimore to assume his
present post.
Reverend Evers, who has many
relatives and a wide contact among
the German people in all walks of
life, has made many trips to his native land since his first arrival in
America. He is described as being
well acquainted with the life and
customs of the German people and
with the popular reaction to the
present regime.

Swarthmore
LANG
PLAY STICK TILTS
Boston Cancelled
To Face Jay Captain Of Lacrosse Team
Of Successful

Jay Speedsters Hopeful Of
Avenging Defeat Suffered
Last Year At Phila.

Meet At Homewood
Team Suffers From Lack Of
Practice, Due To Recent
Inclement Weather
In an attempt to gain revenge for
last season's defeat, the Johns Hopkins track team will face the
Swarthmore runners in the opening
'meet of the season. The contest
will start at one o'clock on Saturday, directly preceding the lacrosse
games.
The two teams have met for the
last three years, with the Pennsylvictories
vanians holding two
against one for the Blue Jays. However, the Black and Blue's cause is
aided by the fact that the engagement is being held at Homewood,
where the Jays won in 1932.
JAYS LACK PRACTICE

The chief handicap confronting
the Hopkins aggregation is the lack
of practice necessary for the opening encounter. Because of the bad
weather, the Jays were unable to
get out of doors as early as was
desired, with the result that they
missed two weeks of valuable training.
Coach Hambleton, nevertheless,
will put a strong squad upon the
field on Saturday and a nip and tuck
battle is expected. The Jays are
particularly powerful in the distance
runs such as the mile and two-mile
events. In the former race, the
Black and Blue will be represented
by King, Sholtes, and Emmert, all
stars on the cross-country team. In
the two-mile
run, Holtzman,
Brown, and Lewis are the best prospects at present, with Johnson and
Froma also showing up well.

Presenting Millard T. Lang,
captain of the lacrosse team, who
has been playing lacrosse for ,seven
successive years. Before coming
to Hopkins where he made the varsity team in his freshman year,
Millard had played at the Baltimore
Polytechnic Institute for four
seasons.
Lang
was
born in Baltimore August 7,
1912, and has
been living here
since. Despite
the fact that his
family moved to
New York a
few years ago,
—Courtesy The Sunpapers
he remained here in order to continue his education at Hopkins. He
will graduate from the School of
Engineering this spring.
Some of the activities he has
taken part in are the Electrical Club
and the Varsity Club. He is now
a member of the Athletic Association. Although Lang's specialty is
lacrosse, he has held a berth on the
Blue Jay football team. In 1932,
he was a member of the Hopkins
lacrosse team that played in the
Olympics.
Like several other members of
the lacrosse team that have been interviewed, Captain Lang feels that
our strongest opposition this, year
will come from Mt. Washington
Country Club. However, he added
that with the fine coaching the squad
is receiving, Hopkins is sure to
have a team that it can be proud of.

Due to the recent inclement
weather, the Boston College tennis
match, which was scheduled for tomorrow, has been cancelled. This
sets back the opening of the current season until Thursday, at which
date Temple will be encountered at
home if the courts are in condition.
The novice tournament, barring
further rain, will begin Monday at
the Homewood courts.
Matches
will be played daily in an effort to
reach the final. round by the end of
the week. Both the winner and the
runner-up will become members of
the varsity squad.

While the Hopkins stickmen are
facing Washington at Homewood
on Saturday, two other Maryland
lacrosse squads are also opening
their season at home.
The University of Maryland will
swing into action against Harvard
at College Park in what promises
to be an interesting battle.
The other team to open its season on Saturday is the Navy.

Other regulars who will compete against Swarthmore are Clark
in the quarter, Neu in the sprints,
Merson and Coburn in the hurdles,
and Chancellor, Weeks, and Moravek in the weights. The events in
which Hopkins is weak are the polevault and the jumps. Because of
the loss of veterans through injury
and graduation, these events are entirely open to new candidates.
Coach Hambleton announced
that due to the extensiveness of the
track schedule, the intramural meet
has been postponed. Although no
definite date has been set, it is supposed that the meet will take place
on the 18th or 19th of April.

Rifle Team Ends
Successful Season
The rifle team experienced
one of its most successful season in
the history of the club during the
current year.
Through twelve
weeks of competitive firing, the
Jays won 55 matches, while losing
24.
The highest scores for three 1)6sitions this year are Wolf 289, Wilson 286, and Miller, 285. Letters
will be awarded in the next few
weeks, on the basis of the number
of meets in which each member
participated, and the individual averages of each contest.
The retiring officers for this year
are T. G. Hull, president; C. U.
Wolf, secretary-treasurer; L. O.
Chancellor, captain; S. N. Cohenberg, manager; and P. W. Guild,
assistant manager.

At last, gentle reader, you are to
have an outlet for the expression
of that great flood of poetic talent
that we know lies latent within you,
eternally awaiting that blessed hour
when it can burst forth in' full maturity. Furthermore, if by our system you go on and on until your
name is ranked with those of Spencer, Chaucer, Milton, and Shelley,
the NEWS-LETTER will meekly and
modestly step to the background
and allow you to reap the full harvest of your melodic outbursts.
Beginning with this issue we intend to publish a series of limericks
anent campus activities and celebriOes.
Your opportunity will
evolve in this fashion—you are to
be the ones who will fill in that fifth
and all-important line of the stanza! Just think of the advantage
that this presents. You will learn
the value of and necessity for brevity and compactness, in that all of
your pent-up emotions and philosophical outlook must be crammed
into that "one line.

HOME WOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 6, 1934

ltemsen Club
Elects Officers
Sachs Heads Chemistry Association Sponsored By
Dr. Neil E. Gordon
At the organization meeting of
he newly founded Remsen Chemistry Club, Robert G. Sachs was
named president of the organization.
The other officers elected were
vice-president, Ned Railing, secretary, Laurence Weiss; treasurer,
Richard Schlotterback ;• and sergeant-at-arms, Floyd Katske.
FOUNDED BY DR. GORDON

The club, started by Dr. Neil E.
Gordon, is an honorary association
the purpose of which is to further
interest in chemistry and to bring
the members into closer contact
with the subject. Although it is a
freshman undertaking, members of
other classes are eligible for membership.
No constitution has as yet been
adopted, but one is being formulated and will be voted upon at the
regular meeting, Thursday. Tentative membership and program committees have been appointed.
The lattter group has announced
that arrangements are being made
to secure prominent speakers.

Wayne E. Lees, former University of Maryland student who was
expelled for his refusal to join the
R. 0. T. C., will speak at a "Student Protest Against War" in Levering Hall, at 4 p. m. today.
The meeting is sponsored by a
new campus group, the Hopkins
League Against War and Facism,
and will mark the seventeenth anniversary of the entrance of the
United States into the World War.
DR. SPARER TO SPEAK

Dr. Jack Sparer, who was_a high
school student at the outbreak of
hostilities and organized 18 New
York high schools to resist the
American declaration of war, will
also speak.
The principal speaker was involved in .the case 'concerning the
legality of compulsory military
training at the State university, recently taken to the United States
He refused to
Supreme Court.
take the military drills required of
all first- and second-year student at
College Park. The trustees of the
University, who insisted on the
compulsory course, won the case.
Jim McNeil will preside, at the
meeting, and other members of the
group will present short talks.

Evers On The Hitler
Regime Today At 1 P. M.
The Rev. Fritz 0. Evers, Zion
Church, Baltimore, will discuss
"The Reactions of the German
People to the Hitler Regime" before the Liberal Club in Room B,
Levering Hall, today at 1 p. in.
Dr. Evers has recently returned
from a several weeks stay in Germany, where as a former German
citizen he had ample opportunity to
observe the feelings of the people
toward their new government.
IS PROMINENT PREACHER.
As a young man, Dr. Evers came
to this country at the beginning of
the century. He preached in Englewood, New Jersey, for a number of
years and then went to Zion Church
Philadelphia. About five years ago
he came to Baltimore to assume his
present post.
Reverend Evers, who has many
relatives and a wide contact among
the German people in all walks of
life, has made many trips to his native land since his first arrival in
America. He is described as being
well acquainted with the life and
customs of the German people and
with the popular reaction to the
present regime.

Meet At Homewood
Team Suffers From Lack Of
Practice, Due To Recent
Inclement Weather
In an attempt to gain revenge for
last season's defeat, the Johns Hopkins track team will face the
Swarthmore runners in the opening
'meet of the season. The contest
will start at one o'clock on Saturday, directly preceding the lacrosse
games.
The two teams have met for the
last three years, with the Pennsylvictories
vanians holding two
against one for the Blue Jays. However, the Black and Blue's cause is
aided by the fact that the engagement is being held at Homewood,
where the Jays won in 1932.
JAYS LACK PRACTICE

The chief handicap confronting
the Hopkins aggregation is the lack
of practice necessary for the opening encounter. Because of the bad
weather, the Jays were unable to
get out of doors as early as was
desired, with the result that they
missed two weeks of valuable training.
Coach Hambleton, nevertheless,
will put a strong squad upon the
field on Saturday and a nip and tuck
battle is expected. The Jays are
particularly powerful in the distance
runs such as the mile and two-mile
events. In the former race, the
Black and Blue will be represented
by King, Sholtes, and Emmert, all
stars on the cross-country team. In
the two-mile
run, Holtzman,
Brown, and Lewis are the best prospects at present, with Johnson and
Froma also showing up well.

Presenting Millard T. Lang,
captain of the lacrosse team, who
has been playing lacrosse for ,seven
successive years. Before coming
to Hopkins where he made the varsity team in his freshman year,
Millard had played at the Baltimore
Polytechnic Institute for four
seasons.
Lang
was
born in Baltimore August 7,
1912, and has
been living here
since. Despite
the fact that his
family moved to
New York a
few years ago,
—Courtesy The Sunpapers
he remained here in order to continue his education at Hopkins. He
will graduate from the School of
Engineering this spring.
Some of the activities he has
taken part in are the Electrical Club
and the Varsity Club. He is now
a member of the Athletic Association. Although Lang's specialty is
lacrosse, he has held a berth on the
Blue Jay football team. In 1932,
he was a member of the Hopkins
lacrosse team that played in the
Olympics.
Like several other members of
the lacrosse team that have been interviewed, Captain Lang feels that
our strongest opposition this, year
will come from Mt. Washington
Country Club. However, he added
that with the fine coaching the squad
is receiving, Hopkins is sure to
have a team that it can be proud of.

Due to the recent inclement
weather, the Boston College tennis
match, which was scheduled for tomorrow, has been cancelled. This
sets back the opening of the current season until Thursday, at which
date Temple will be encountered at
home if the courts are in condition.
The novice tournament, barring
further rain, will begin Monday at
the Homewood courts.
Matches
will be played daily in an effort to
reach the final. round by the end of
the week. Both the winner and the
runner-up will become members of
the varsity squad.

While the Hopkins stickmen are
facing Washington at Homewood
on Saturday, two other Maryland
lacrosse squads are also opening
their season at home.
The University of Maryland will
swing into action against Harvard
at College Park in what promises
to be an interesting battle.
The other team to open its season on Saturday is the Navy.

CLARK, NEU TO COMPETE

Other regulars who will compete against Swarthmore are Clark
in the quarter, Neu in the sprints,
Merson and Coburn in the hurdles,
and Chancellor, Weeks, and Moravek in the weights. The events in
which Hopkins is weak are the polevault and the jumps. Because of
the loss of veterans through injury
and graduation, these events are entirely open to new candidates.
Coach Hambleton announced
that due to the extensiveness of the
track schedule, the intramural meet
has been postponed. Although no
definite date has been set, it is supposed that the meet will take place
on the 18th or 19th of April.

Rifle Team Ends
Successful Season
The rifle team experienced
one of its most successful season in
the history of the club during the
current year.
Through twelve
weeks of competitive firing, the
Jays won 55 matches, while losing
24.
The highest scores for three 1)6sitions this year are Wolf 289, Wilson 286, and Miller, 285. Letters
will be awarded in the next few
weeks, on the basis of the number
of meets in which each member
participated, and the individual averages of each contest.
The retiring officers for this year
are T. G. Hull, president; C. U.
Wolf, secretary-treasurer; L. O.
Chancellor, captain; S. N. Cohenberg, manager; and P. W. Guild,
assistant manager.
